question:
The relatives of a group of pelicans from the same species that separated from each other because of an unsuccessful migration are reunited 150 years later and find that they are unable to produce offspring. This is an example of
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. allopatric speciation.
B. sympatric speciation.
C. genetic drift.
D. gene flow.
Answer:

Protein that prevents the binding of RNA polymerase to the promoter site.
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Enhancer
B. Repressor
C. Operator
D. Promoter
Answer:

In a population of giraffes, an environmental change occurs that favors individuals that are tallest. As a result, more of the taller individuals are able to obtain nutrients and survive to pass along their genetic information. This is an example of
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. directional selection.
B. stabilizing selection.
C. sexual selection.
D. disruptive selection.
Answer:

Some strains of viruses can change normal mammalian cells into cancer cells in vitro. This transformation of the mammalian cell is usually associated with the
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. formation of a pilus between the mammalian cell and the virus
B. incorporation of the viral genome into the mammalian cell's nuclear DNA
C. conversion of the host's genome into the viral DNA
D. release of spores into the mammalian cell
Answer:

Which of the following is an example of a cline?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. The hybrid tomato plant is stronger and produces better fruit than the pure genotype.
B. There are two distinct varieties in one population of snail that inhabits an island in the Pacific Ocean.
C. Males of some species have long antlers to fight other males for females.
D. In one species of rabbit, the ones that evolved in the cold, snowy north are white, while the ones that evolved in the south are brown.
Answer:

Stretching out from the equator is a wide belt of tropical rain forests that are being cut down to provide exotic woods for export to the U.S. and to make land available to graze beef cattle. Which of the following statements is a negative consequence of clear-cutting the tropical rain forests?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Indigenous populations will have access to modern conveniences.
B. There will be less precipitation in those clear-cut areas.
C. U.S. markets will have access to less expensive beef.
D. Deforestation will allow more sunlight to penetrate areas that were kept dark by dense vegetation.
Answer:

Two trees of the same species growing close together will use the same resources, such as light, water, and nutrients. If any of these resources becomes limiting, then each tree will receive less of it than if the trees were growing farther apart. This scenario is an example of which of the following?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Parasitism
B. Commensalism
C. Natural selection
D. Intraspecific competition
Answer:

What is the best explanation for the fact that tuna, sharks, and dolphins all have a similar streamlined appearance?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. They all share a recent common ancestor.
B. They all sustained the same set of mutations.
C. They acquire a streamlined body type to survive in their particular environment.
D. The streamlined body has a selective advantage in that environment.
Answer:

Nymphaea odorata, a water lily, is an aquatic plant whose leaves and flowers float on the surface of the water. Which of the following characteristics would be expected for leaves of this plant?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. stomata on the top surface and relatively few water-conducting (xylem) cells
B. stomata on the top surface and relatively many water-conducting (xylem) cells
C. stomata on the bottom surface and relatively few water-conducting (xylem) cells
D. stomata on the bottom surface and relatively many water-conducting (xylem) cells
Answer:

High levels of estrogen from maturing follicles inhibit the release of gonadotropin releasing hormone (GnRH). Which of the following endocrine glands produces GnRH?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Anterior pituitary
B. Posterior pituitary
C. Hypothalamus
D. Pineal gland
Answer:

Which of the following is most likely to increase the rate of diffusion of an uncharged solute across the plasma membrane of a cell?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Decreasing the number of different solutes in the solution that bathes the cells
B. Increasing the concentration gradient of the solute across the membrane
C. Increasing the ratio of phospholipids to proteins in the membrane
D. Decreasing the membrane potential across the membrane
Answer:

Many different fermentation pathways occur in different organisms in nature. For example, skeletal muscle cells convert pyruvate into lactic acid when no oxygen is present. Yeast cells can produce alcohol and carbon dioxide under the same circumstances. However, regardless of the specific reactions, the purpose of glycolysis is an important one. Which statement best describes the importance of glycolysis?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. It produces large amounts of ATP by substrate level phosphorylation.
B. It reoxidizes NADH so that glycolysis can continue.
C. It produces pyruvate, which is the raw material for oxidative phosphorylation.
D. It occurs in the cytoplasm.
Answer:

Compared to DNA viral replication, RNA viral replication is more susceptible to mutation because
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. RNA replication takes place in the cytoplasm, whereas DNA replication takes place in the nucleus.
B. RNA viruses replicate much faster than DNA viruses.
C. RNA viruses use uracil instead of thymine.
D. RNA replication lacks the proofreading functions characteristic of DNA replication.
Answer:

A heterotroph
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. obtains its energy from sunlight, harnessed by pigments
B. obtains its energy by oxidizing organic molecules
C. makes organic molecules from CO2
D. obtains its energy by consuming exclusively autotrophs
Answer:

Within a cell, the amount of protein synthesized using a given mRNA molecule depends in part on which of the following?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. DNA methylation suppresses the expression of genes.
B. Transcription factors mediate the binding of RNA polymerase and the initiation of transcription, which will determine how much protein is manufactured.
C. The speed with which mRNA is degraded will determine how much protein is synthesized.
D. The location and number of ribosomes in a cell will solely determine how much protein is synthesized.
Answer:

A cell is placed into a hypertonic environment and its cytoplasm shrivels up. This demonstrates the principle of
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. diffusion.
B. active transport.
C. facilitated diffusion.
D. plasmolysis.
Answer:

Which of the following is an incorrect statement about gel electrophoresis?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. DNA migrates from positive charge to negative charge.
B. Smaller DNA travels faster.
C. The DNA migrates only when the current is running.
D. The longer the current is running, the farther the DNA will travel.
Answer:

The energy given up by electrons as they move through the electron transport chain is used to
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. break down glucose
B. make glucose
C. produce ATP
D. make NADH
Answer:

A lizard lacking a chemical defense mechanism that is colored in the same way as a lizard that has a defense mechanism is displaying
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. aposometric coloration.
B. cryptic coloration.
C. Batesian mimicry.
D. MÃ¼llerian mimicry.
Answer:

An animal that is harmless copies the appearance of an animal that is dangerous as a defense mechanism to make predators think twice about attacking.
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Aposomatic coloration
B. Batesian mimicry
C. Deceptive markings
D. Cryptic coloration
Answer:

This process leads to the net production of two pyruvate, two ATP, and two NADH.
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Glycolysis
B. Chemiosmosis
C. Fermentation
D. Calvin cycle
Answer:

Which of the following theories is based on the notion that mitochondria and chloroplasts evolved from prokaryotic cells?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Fluid mosaic model
B. Endosymbiotic model
C. Taxonomic model
D. Respiration feedback model
Answer:

Which of the following best explains why drinking breast milk is beneficial to a human infant?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Breast milk contains vitamins that repair mutations originating in the sperm or egg.
B. Breast milk contains maternal antibodies that protect against gastrointestinal pathogens.
C. Breast milk contains maternal vaccines that destroy common childhood pathogens.
D. Breast milk contains red blood cells with adult hemoglobin that are beneficial to the infant's developing brain.
Answer:

Logically, which of these should cast the most doubt on the relationships depicted by an evolutionary tree?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. None of the organisms depicted by the tree ate the same foods.
B. Some of the organisms depicted by the tree had lived in different habitats.
C. The skeletal remains of the organisms depicted by the tree were incomplete (i.e., some bones were missing).
D. Relationships between DNA sequences among the species did not match relationships between skeletal patterns.
Answer:

A scientist carries out a cross between two guinea pigs, both of which have black coats. Black hair coat is dominant over white hair coat. Three quarters of the offspring have black coats, and one quarter have white coats. The genotypes of the parents were most likely
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. bb Ã bb
B. Bb Ã Bb
C. Bb Ã bb
D. BB Ã Bb
Answer:

Kangaroo rats are better able to concentrate urine than humans are. It would be expected that, compared to the nephrons of human kidneys, the nephrons of kangaroo-rat kidneys would have
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. thicker walls, which are impermeable to water
B. shorter loops of Henle
C. longer loops of Henle
D. shorter collecting ducts
Answer:

When driving from east to west in the U.S. from a forest ecosystem to grasslands, trees gradually give way to grasses. Which of the following is the critical factor responsible for this shift?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Amount of sunlight
B. Availability of oxygen
C. Availability of water
D. Length of growing season
Answer:

Which of the following best summarizes the process of allopatric speciation?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. differential changes in allele frequencies â reproductive isolation â reproductive barriers â new species
B. catastrophic event â reproductive isolation â reproductive barriers â new species
C. reproductive isolation â differential changes in allele frequencies â reproductive barriers â new species
D. geographic isolation â reproductive isolation â differential changes in allele frequencies â reproductive barriers â new species
Answer:

A proficient engineer can easily design skeletal structures that are more functional than those currently found in the forelimbs of such diverse mammals as horses, whales, and bats. That the actual forelimbs of these mammals do not seem to be optimally arranged is because
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. natural selection has not had sufficient time to create the optimal design in each case, but will do so given enough time.
B. natural selection operates in ways that are beyond the capability of the human mind to comprehend.
C. in many cases, phenotype is not merely determined by genotype, but by the environment as well.
D. natural selection is generally limited to modifying structures that were present in previous generations and in previous species.
Answer:

African lungfish often live in small, stagnant, freshwater pools. With reduced gills, they differ from other fish in that they breathe air. They also differ in that they release the nitrogen waste urea instead of ammonia. Which of the following statements correctly explains how this is an advantage for lungfish?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Urea is insoluble in water and sinks to the bottom of the small pools. Thus the poisonous substance is isolated from the fish.
B. Ammonia, which is highly toxic, would endanger lungfish that inhabit the small pools.
C. Other fish in the small pools can use urea as an energy source.
D. The highly toxic urea makes the pool uninhabitable to competitors.
Answer:

In a certain pond, there are long-finned fish and short-finned fish. A horrific summer thunderstorm leads to the death of a disproportionate number of long-finned fish to the point where the relative frequency of the two forms has drastically shifted. This is an example of
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. gene flow.
B. natural selection.
C. genetic drift.
D. stabilizing selection.
Answer:

Which of the following statements best explains why Mendel's principle of segregation was deemed a law?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Mendel's work with pea plants and his conclusions have been described in many sources.
B. The patterns of trait inheritance observed in pea plants were repeatedly demonstrated in other eukaryotes.
C. Chromosomes were found to contain the genetic information for traits.
D. The discovery of the structure of D N A supported Mendel's observations and laws.
Answer:

It has been observed that organisms on islands are different from, but closely related to, similar forms found on the nearest continent. This is taken as evidence that
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. 0
B. common environments are inhabited by the same organisms.
C. the islands were originally part of the continent.
D. the island forms and mainland forms are converging.
Answer:

Which of the following statements about cellular respiration is correct?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Most CO2 produced during cellular respiration is released from glycolysis.
B. Protons are pumped through ATP synthase by active transport.
C. The final electron acceptor of the electron transport chain is NAD+.
D. ATP is formed because an endergonic reaction is coupled with an exergonic reaction.
Answer:

Which of the following statements most detracts from the claim that the human appendix is a completely vestigial organ?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. The appendix can be surgically removed with no immediate ill effects.
B. The appendix might have been larger in fossil hominids.
C. The appendix has a substantial amount of defensive lymphatic tissue.
D. Individuals with a larger-than-average appendix leave fewer offspring than those with a below-average-sized appendix.
Answer:

Although mutations occur at a regular and predictable rate, which of the following statements is the LEAST likely reason the frequency of mutation appears to be low?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Some mutations produce alleles that are recessive and may not be expressed.
B. Some undesirable phenotypic traits may be prevented from reproducing.
C. Some mutations cause such drastic phenotypic changes that they are removed from the gene pool.
D. The predictable rate of mutation results in ongoing variability in a gene pool.
Answer:

A piece of potato is dropped into a beaker of pure water. Which of the following describes the initial condition when the potato enters the water?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. The water potential of the pure water is negative.
B. The water potential of the pure water is positive.
C. The water potential of the potato is positive.
D. The water potential of the potato is negative.
Answer:

The pH of two lakes is measured. Lake A has a pH of 8.0; Lake B has a pH of 6.0. Which of the following statements is correct about these lakes?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Lake B is alkaline.
B. Lake B is 100 times more alkaline than Lake A.
C. The hydrogen ion concentration of Lake B is 104 M.
D. The pH of both lakes will decrease in response to acid rain.
Answer:

Which of the following would most likely provide examples of mitotic cell divisions?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. cross section of muscle tissue
B. cross section of an anther (site of pollen production in a flower)
C. longitudinal section of a shoot tip
D. cross section of a leaf
Answer:

Members of which of the following groups are most likely to be surrounded by a protein coat?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Viruses
B. Bacteria
C. Eukaryotes
D. Archaea
Answer:

A child with type A B blood inherits an IA allele from one parent and an IB allele from the other. The child will carry both A and B glycoproteins on the surface of all red blood cells. This pattern of expression is referred to as
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. codominance
B. epistasis
C. polygenic
D. linkage
Answer:

A certain species of land snail exists as either a cream color or a solid brown color. Intermediate individuals are relatively rare. Which of the following terms best describes this?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. artificial selection
B. directional selection
C. stabilizing selection
D. disruptive selection
Answer:

The tandem back-and-forth evolution of closely related species, which is exemplified by predator-prey relationships.
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Divergent evolution
B. Convergent evolution
C. Parallel evolution
D. Coevolution
Answer:

Which of the following pairs of scientists pioneered the ecological discipline known as island biogeography?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Robert MacArthur and E. O. Wilson
B. James Watson and Francis Crick
C. Matthias Schleiden and Theodor Schwann
D. Alfred Hershey and Martha Chase
Answer:

If a couple has had three sons and the woman is pregnant with their fourth child, what is the probability that child 4 will also be male?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. 1/2
B. 1/4
C. 1/8
D. 1/16
Answer:

A baby duck runs for cover when a large object is tossed over its head. After this object is repeatedly passed overhead, the duck learns there is no danger and stops running for cover when the same object appears again. This is an example of
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. imprinting.
B. fixed-action pattern.
C. agonistic behavior.
D. habituation.
Answer:

Oligomycin is an antibiotic that blocks proton channels in the cristae of mitochondria by binding to ATP synthase. Which of the following would be the first expected response after the application of oligomycin to cells?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Water production would increase.
B. H+ would increase inside the intermembrane space (the compartment between inner and outer membranes).
C. H+ would increase in the matrix (inside mitochondrial inner membrane).
D. H+ would increase outside mitochondria.
Answer:

The major difference between cartilage and bone is that cartilage
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. is a part of the skeletal system
B. is composed of collagen and salts
C. lacks blood vessels and nerves
D. secretes a matrix
Answer:

Which of the following statements is NOT correct about ancient Earth?
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. Earth was formed about 4? billion years ago.
B. Amino acid synthesis could have been stimulated by volcanic eruption.
C. The first cells formed about 3? billion years ago, according to the fossil record.
D. The presence of free oxygen facilitated the rapid formation of organic molecules.
Answer:

A form of species interaction in which one of the species benefits while the other is unaffected is called
Choose the best answer from the following options:
A. parasitism.
B. mutualism.
C. commensalism.
D. symbiosis.
Answer:
